I think what's helping us there is, frankly, we've invested a lot more in go-to-market and the go-to-market investments are paying-off. The enterprise sales cycle is often a 6-month to 9-month sales cycle. But as we've invested more resources in it throughout 2024, we've seen that convert into a significant number of new POCs that are now converting into volume deployments. And as we go through into 2025, from a competitiveness standpoint, we have a very strong portfolio across every price point, every core count, every workload. So I think, we see a strong 2025 for server CPUs.

transcript.speaker: Harlan Sur
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: I appreciate that. Networking is a very critical part of the AI infrastructure becoming even more important. There seems to be this misconception that AMD is behind the curve here, you're keeping pace kind of leveraging the incumbent Ethernet technology, strong installed ecosystem. You guys are spearheading the UltraNET Ethernet Consortium. You've got your Infinity Fabric technology for scale-up connectivity does you continue to drive customer adoption of your overall AI platforms. What's the feedback been like on your AI networking architectures? And any networking-related innovations the team is going to be bringing to the market this year?

transcript.speaker: Lisa Su
transcript.title: Chair and CEO
transcript.content: Yes. Thanks, Harlan, for that question. No question. Networking is an extremely important part of the AI solution, and it's an area that we have been investing and spending quite a bit of effort with our customers and our partners jointly. The way to think about it is that our networking proof points are actually increasing as we are going from MI300 to MI325 to MI350 to MI400. So in each of those points, we are increasing with a number of proof points. I think people want to see more clusters of ours. Certainly, on inference, we've shown great performance and total cost of ownership. We are now also have a number of training systems that we are putting on board. And the important part there is the networking. We have worked very closely with our partners on Ethernet. We believe that this is the right technology for the future. In addition to third-party networking solutions, we are also with our Pensando team developing our own in-house AI NIC that Forrest mentioned at our Q4 advancing AI event. And as we look forward, working with our customers, we are actually standing up full rack solutions at both the MI350 level as well as in the MI400 series. So I think the net of it is we believe that, yes, it is absolutely very important. And in addition to all of the hardware and software work, the system level scaling is super important and we are on track to deliver that with our roadmap.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: And the next question comes from the line of Blayne Curtis with Jefferies. Please proceed with your question.

transcript.speaker: Blayne Curtis
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Hi, thanks for taking my question. Lisa, I just want to follow up the data center GPU business, obviously, very strongly year-over-year, but it seems for your commentary kind of the sequential growth slows for the next kind of three quarters. So I just want to understand the why. Obviously, you have some new products coming. So maybe it's just the shift to the new products. I also want to just ping your brain on in terms of when you look at the ASIC story lines, there tends to be kind of a shift to focus on training versus inference. So just your perspective, I know a lot of your workloads initially were inference. Are you seeing any shift in terms of the demand from your customers between training inference as well?

transcript.speaker: Lisa Su
transcript.title: Chair and CEO
transcript.content: Yes, we saw significant growth as we developed the data center GPU business throughout 2024. We are continuing to implement new deployments and attract new customers. We are experiencing a transition period for our products in the first half of the year. The introduction of the MI350 series has been crucial for us and our customer base. The fact that this hardware has been successfully launched, and what we've learned from the initial MI300 deployments, are positive indicators given the overall deployment landscape. Regarding ASICs, there hasn't been a major change in discussions. Customers appreciate our work in inference but want to see us as a robust training option, which aligns with our planned roadmap for those solutions. On the software front, we've made significant investments in our training libraries, and the focus is on entering data centers and increasing the deployment of GPUs. Overall, we're making solid progress. I want to emphasize that while ASICs are part of the solution, they are also an integral component of AMD's offerings. We have a long history of semi-custom solutions and are actively engaged in several ASIC discussions with our customers, who prefer to build on our foundational IP for innovation. This capability sets us apart since we have all the essential building blocks, including CPUs, GPUs, and networking technologies, needed to create comprehensive solutions.

transcript.speaker: Matt Ramsey
transcript.title: Vice President of Investor Relations
transcript.content: Operator, I think we have time for two more callers, please.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: Okay. The next question comes from the line of Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein Research. Please proceed.

transcript.speaker: Stacy Rasgon
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Hi, everyone. Thank you for taking my questions. I want to be more specific. You mentioned that your server business experienced strong double-digit growth sequentially in Q4. My calculations suggest that this might imply a decline in the GPU business sequentially. Considering your guidance for mostly flat GPU sales in the first half of '25 compared to the second half of '24, does my math indicate that you could see a sequential decline in both Q1 and Q2? Am I misunderstanding something in my calculations?

transcript.speaker: Lisa Su
transcript.title: Chair and CEO
transcript.content: Yes, Stacy, let me provide some clarification. We did not indicate strong double-digit growth; we mentioned double digits. The data center segment increased by 9% sequentially, with the server growth exceeding that and the data center GPU growth being slightly lower. For some of the models currently available, the Q3 data center GPU numbers may be somewhat lower than expected, which could require some adjustments. Therefore, it wouldn't be correct to interpret it as you suggested. If we consider the growth from the second half of '24 to the first half of '25, it appears to be roughly flat, plus or minus. We'll have to monitor the timing of deployments closely, but that is our current outlook.

transcript.speaker: Stacy Rasgon
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Got it. Thanks. And I guess for my follow-up, maybe to follow on there, do you think your exit rate on GPUs in '25 is higher than your exit rate in '24. Are you willing to commit to that?

transcript.speaker: Lisa Su
transcript.title: Chair and CEO
transcript.content: Absolutely. But yes, of course. It would be hard to grow strong double digits otherwise, right?

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: And the final question comes from the line of Toshiya Hari with Goldman Sachs. Please proceed with your question.

transcript.speaker: Toshiya Hari
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Hi, thank you so much for squeezing me in. Lisa, I had a question on the server CPU business. I'm curious how you're thinking about the market this year? And if you can delineate between cloud and enterprise, that would be really helpful. And then kind of part B to that question. In your prepared remarks, you talked about you all having more than 50% share across the major hyperscalers. How would you characterize the competitive intensity at those customers vis-a-vis some of the internal custom silicon that's expected to ramp over the coming quarters and years?

transcript.speaker: Lisa Su
transcript.title: Chair and CEO
transcript.content: Sure, Toshiya. As we look ahead to 2025, we anticipate a strong server market for both cloud and enterprise sectors. In the early part of 2024, there was a slight decrease in investments on the CPU side as companies focused their spending on AI initiatives. However, we observed a rebound in investments during the second half of 2024, and we expect this trend to continue into 2025. The refresh cycles in enterprise are starting again, and many cloud vendors are also updating their data centers.

transcript.speaker: Toshiya Hari
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: Competitive custom silicon.

transcript.speaker: Lisa Su
transcript.title: Chair and CEO
transcript.content: Yes. Look, I think it's about the same. What I would say, Toshiya is, it is less about custom silicon versus x86. It is much more about do you have the right product for the right workload. And look, the server market is always a competitive market. What we've done, and you've seen it in our Zen 4 product line as well as in our Zen 5 product line. We've expanded the design points for each of the core generation so that we have cloud native and then we have enterprise optimized low core count, high core count, highest performance, best perf per dollar. And I think as we do those things, I think we’re continuing to grow share across both cloud and enterprise. And look, it is always very competitive. We take every design win with very seriously, but we are winning our fair share. And I think that's the strength of the product portfolio. And also, I think there is a good amount of trust for our delivery capability as we've built up our sort of our franchise over the last number of years.

transcript.speaker: Toshiya Hari
transcript.title: Analyst
transcript.content: That's great. And then as a quick follow-up, maybe one for Jean. So you're guiding gross margin to 54% in the first quarter. I'm curious what some of the major puts and takes are and those are the things that we should be cognizant of going into Q2 and more importantly, the second half. Given your data center commentary skewed more to the second half, I would expect margins to improve in the second half. But yes, if you can kind of run through the pluses and minuses, that would be really helpful. Thank you.

transcript.speaker: Jean Hu
transcript.title: CFO
transcript.content: Yes. Thanks for the question. You are right. Our gross margin is primarily driven by our revenue mix, I think when you look at looking to 2025, Q1 guide, not only data center continued to grow significantly year-over-year. At the same time, client business is also growing year-over-year. So overall, the revenue mix is quite consistent with the Q4. So the gross margin guide is 54%. I think for the first half, if the revenue mix is at this level, we do feel the gross margin will be consistent with 54%. But going into second half, we do believe the data center is our fastest growth driver for the company and that will drive the gross margin to step up in the second half.

transcript.speaker: Matt Ramsey
transcript.title: Vice President of Investor Relations
transcript.content: All right. With that, I think we are ready to close the call now, operator. I just wanted to say thank you to everybody that listened and participated today and for your interest in AMD. Thank you very much.

transcript.speaker: Operator
transcript.title: Operator
transcript.content: Thank you. And ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude today's teleconference. We thank you for your participation. You may disconnect your lines at this time.
